>So said javainsel on 2003-05-04 --------------------
>> There are differen=
t kinds of test coverage, measured by the 
>aspects of the program they cov=
er. 100% line coverage seems to be 
>the most definite of the ones you list=
, although it does not take 
>into account different data sets. It is possi=
ble to have 100% line 
>coverage and still have a defect because you have n=
ot written code 
>to handle a particular case.
>> 
>> I do not like test co=
verage measurement. It is not smart enough. 
>Obviously, 90% coverage is mu=
ch better than 50% coverage, but the 
>return on investment goes down consi=
derably up over 90%. My opinion.
>> 
>> Take care.
>
>I have no real practi=
cal interest in this. It is theoretical 
>curiosity.
>
>You are right with =
the 100% objection. I meant a measure which 
>covers everything. If all tes=
ts are written to the results of that 
>measure and the tests are all green=
 then I think it is proven that 
>there are no bugs in the code (if the tes=
t has no bugs itself).

If you measure X then you get X, no matter what X i=
s. If you measure lines of code, you get more code. If you measure branch c=
overage, you get tests that cover more branches, whether those branches are=
 actually useful is immaterial. That's why I only like one message: Feature=
s the Customer Likes that Work.

>Thats what I am looking for. The super du=
per measure.
>
>Any idea?

No, because Test-Driven Development guarantees s=
ufficiently high coverage, so I haven't found measuring test coverage to be=
 useful. That's just personal taste.

Take care.


J. B. Rainsberger,
